title: How to Grow a Garden in a Bottle

steps.title: Select plants that require similar growing conditions.
steps.content: Select plants that require similar growing conditions. If you’re growing multiple plants in a bottle terrarium, it’s important to select species that have similar requirements for light, moisture, and soil type. Choose your plants before you start assembling your bottle garden so that you can plan for their needs. [1] X Research source For example, if you want to grow succulents, you might choose zebra haworthia, hens-and-chicks, and kalanchoe. [2] X Research source For a bottle garden with a moister environment, you could go for peace lilies, Fittonia, and Syngonium.

steps.title: Choose a large, clear glass bottle or jar for your plants.
steps.content: Choose a large, clear glass bottle or jar for your plants. Look for a glass bottle or jar that’s large enough to accommodate the type and number of plants you want to grow. The glass should be clear and colorless to allow in light and let you see the plants easily. [3] X Research source You can reuse your own containers, such as jam jars or glass milk jugs, or purchase a glass bottle online or from a craft store. If you choose to reuse a bottle, wash it thoroughly before adding plants. For easier planting, choose a jar or bottle with an opening large enough to allow your hand in. Otherwise, you can use a long pair of tweezers or chopsticks to insert the plants.

steps.title: Get a bottle that can be closed for a more humid environment.
steps.content: Get a bottle that can be closed for a more humid environment. If you’re growing plants that enjoy a moist environment, a closed bottle terrarium is a fun, low-maintenance option. Choose a bottle that you can close with a lid or stopper to prevent evaporation and eliminate the need for frequent watering. [4] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Ideally, your bottle should have a clear cover, such as a glass lid or stopper. However, a small cork stopper will also work if the bottle allows in enough light otherwise.

steps.title: Opt for an open bottle if your plants need less water.
steps.content: Opt for an open bottle if your plants need less water. For succulents and other plants that grow in arid environments, an open bottle, jar, or fishbowl-style container is a better option. This will allow water to evaporate more quickly so that your plants don’t get waterlogged. [5] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source A container with straight sides and a wide opening, such as a jar, will allow for faster evaporation. If you still want a relatively humid environment but don’t want a completely closed ecosystem, choose a bottle with slanted or curved sides and a narrow opening.

steps.title: Add 2 inches (5.1 cm) of horticultural grit to the bottom of the bottle.
steps.content: Add 2 inches (5.1 cm) of horticultural grit to the bottom of the bottle. You’ll need to provide good drainage so that your plants don’t become waterlogged, which can lead to root rot and yellowing leaves. [6] X Trustworthy Source Missouri Botanical Garden Oldest botanical garden in the U.S. and center for botanical research and science education Go to source Pour a little horticultural grit or some small, clean pebbles into the bottom of your bottle so that excess water will pool there instead of around your plants’ roots. [7] X Research source You can buy horticultural grit or planting gravel online or from your local garden supply center.

steps.title: Purchase a potting soil that’s appropriate for your plants.
steps.content: Purchase a potting soil that’s appropriate for your plants. The type of potting soil you choose will depend on the level of moisture and the types of nutrients your plants require. In general, though, it will need to be well-draining, high in organic content, and free of contaminants that might cause infections in your plants. [8] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Research the kind of potting soil that’s best for the plants you plan to grow and buy an appropriate mixture at your local garden center. For example, for succulents, use a 50/50 mixture of soil and sand, which won't hold onto any excess moisture. For more moisture-loving plants, such as peace lilies, opt for a general-purpose houseplant soil that holds a little moisture while still draining well.

steps.title: Put in a layer of potting soil until the bottle is 1/3 full.
steps.content: Put in a layer of potting soil until the bottle is 1/3 full. Pour the soil into the bottle on top of the horticultural grit. Break up any lumps with your hands so that the soil is loose and airy. [10] X Research source It can be helpful to moisten the soil slightly before you pour it in to prevent the sides of the bottle from getting dusty. [11] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source

steps.title: Plan how you would like the plants to be arranged in the bottle.
steps.content: Plan how you would like the plants to be arranged in the bottle. Before you add plants to your bottle, consider what layout you think would be most attractive. Set the plants out on a flat surface and space them out similarly to the way they will be in the bottle. [12] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source For the best visibility, put low plants toward the front and taller ones at the back.

steps.title: Trim your plants and brush off their roots as needed.
steps.content: Trim your plants and brush off their roots as needed. Inspect each plant carefully for signs of disease, insect infestations, or yellowing leaves. Trim away any damaged or unhealthy-looking foliage. Right before you add each plant to the bottle, carefully brush any excess potting soil or growing medium from their roots. [13] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source If the roots are extremely dense inside the original container, gently tease the root ball apart with your fingers. You can even trim away some of the roots to help encourage new roots to branch out.

steps.title: Insert each plant into the container one at a time.
steps.content: Insert each plant into the container one at a time. Use your fingers or a stick to make a depression in the soil where you want each plant. Carefully lower your plants into the bottle and cover their roots with soil. If you’re planting multiple plants, try to leave a little space between them so they have room to spread out. [14] X Research source If your bottle has a narrow opening, you may need to use tongs to insert the plants. Wrap the plants with paper before putting them in to protect the leaves as they pass through the opening. [15] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Try to position the plants so their foliage doesn’t touch the sides of the bottle, since moisture will tend to accumulate on the interior walls. Too much moisture can make the leaves rot.

steps.title: Tamp down the soil around each plant for stability.
steps.content: Tamp down the soil around each plant for stability. Once the plants are in place, pat down the soil around the base of each plant. If the container has a wide enough opening, you can do this with your fingers. Otherwise, you will need to use a tool, such as a skewer or stick with a cork on the end. [16] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Patting down the soil will help remove air pockets and improve contact between the roots and the soil.

steps.title: Fill the spaces between the plants with moss.
steps.content: Fill the spaces between the plants with moss. You can give your terrarium a prettier, more finished appearance by filling the spaces between the plants. Try adding a layer of moss from your garden to create a dreamy, fairy garden look. [17] X Research source You can also use peat moss, gravel, polished pebbles, or sand. [18] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source

steps.title: Pour a small amount of water into the bottle so it runs down the sides.
steps.content: Pour a small amount of water into the bottle so it runs down the sides. Take a watering can and carefully pour in some water along the inner edge of the bottle. Try to get the water to trickle along the wall of the bottle so it doesn’t pour directly onto the plants. Water the soil until it’s damp, but not soggy. [19] X Research source The curved sides of the bottle will help keep the inside of your container nice and moist between waterings. If you wish, you can put a lid on the bottle to maintain an even more humid environment. Alternatively, you can mist the plants instead of watering them. This will help wash off loose potting medium and prevent the soil from getting too sodden, especially if you already moistened it before planting. [20] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source

steps.title: Place your bottle in a well-lit area out of direct sunlight.
steps.content: Place your bottle in a well-lit area out of direct sunlight. Most terrarium plants don’t need direct sun, but they will need some light to grow and stay healthy. Choose a spot in your home that stays bright but won’t allow in enough sun to scorch your plants. [21] X Research source East-facing windows often work well for this purpose. You can also use a grow light if your home doesn’t have any suitable windows.

steps.title: Water your plants when the soil becomes dry.
steps.content: Water your plants when the soil becomes dry. Check the soil in your bottle garden occasionally to make sure it doesn’t dry out completely. Mist the plants or add more water as needed. Most terrarium plants do best if their soil is always slightly moist. [22] X Research source If your bottle terrarium is closed, you probably won’t need to water it for at least 4-6 months. [23] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source If you’re growing succulents, let the soil dry out completely between waterings.

steps.title: Remove any dead or diseased foliage.
steps.content: Remove any dead or diseased foliage. During the first few weeks after planting your garden, observe closely for any signs of disease or rot. Quickly remove any dead or rotting plants or leaves to prevent the spread of disease to other plants in the garden. Take out and replace any growing medium that has signs of fungus in it, and add a plant fungicide to stop the infection from spreading. [24] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Mold can be a sign of an overly humid environment in the bottle. If you’re using a closed bottle for your garden, take off the cover for a few weeks to give it a chance to air out, especially if you notice mold along with fog or condensation on the glass.

steps.title: Prune your plants if they start to get too big.
steps.content: Prune your plants if they start to get too big. Plants grown in a bottle garden sometimes need pruning. If your plants are starting to become too tall for their space, trim them back a little to encourage them to grow out instead of up. [25] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source Proactively trim or pinch off just the tips instead of pruning back most of the foliage after the plant has already gotten too tall. This will encourage healthier growth. Remember to disinfect your pruning tool with isopropyl alcohol to prevent the potential spread of disease to other plants.
